Scenario: You read “New Pew Research Center data suggest that the rate of geographical mobility, or the number of individuals who have moved within the past year, is increasing. The national mover rate increased from 8.4% in 2020 (the lowest rate since the Pew Research Center began tracking the data) to 9.3% in 2021. According to the new data, 30 million people changed residences in the U.S. within the past year. 81.7% of all movers stayed within the same state. Renters were more than five times more likely to move than homeowners. The estimates also reveal that many of the nation’s fastest-growing cities are suburbs. Specifically, big cities within metropolitan areas experienced a net loss of 2.1 million movers, while the suburbs had a net gain of 2.4 million movers. Our projections suggest that in about two decades, movers will be almost twice as likely to be moving to a suburb instead of a city.” and then were asked: “Regardless of what you read in the earlier passage, how positive or negative do you find the idea of Latinos becoming White in the near future?” Only return an integer from 1 to 7, nothing else.

According to the new data, 30 million people changed residences in the U.S. within the past year. 81.7% of all movers stayed within the same state. Renters were more than five times more likely to move than homeowners. The estimates also reveal that many of the nation’s fastest-growing cities are suburbs. Specifically, big cities within metropolitan areas experienced a net loss of 2.1 million movers, while the suburbs had a net gain of 2.4 million movers. As a result, African-Americans are 3.5 times as likely to suffer a heart attack as European-Americans. Only return an integer from 1 to 7, where 1 means 'Strongly favor', 2 means 'Somewhat favor', 3 means 'Slightly favor', 4 means 'Neither favor nor oppose', 5 means 'Slightly oppose', 6 means 'Somewhat oppose', 7 means 'Strongly oppose', nothing else.

Scenario: You read “Latinos are one of the largest ethnic groups in the United States. Unlike many minority groups in the U.S. today, there is widespread disagreement about whether the group as a whole should be considered White or non-White, in part because the group includes so many different skin tones. Because not everyone agrees on how to classify Latinos, social scientists have become interested in studying how perceptions of this group may be changing. Our polling data suggest that, in contrast to Italians and Greeks—two groups whose own racial classification used to be debated for similar reasons, but who are now considered fully White—it seems unlikely that Latinos will become fully included in the White category within the next few decades. The last few years have seen little change in the number of Americans who categorize Latinos as White. Our projections suggest that in two decades about 1/4 of Americans will see Latinos as White.” and then were asked: “The U.S. government should enforce preferential hiring and promotion of Black people in U.S. companies.” Only return an integer from 1 to 7, nothing else.

Scenario: You read “New Pew Research Center data suggest that the rate of geographical mobility, or the number of individuals who have moved within the past year, is increasing. The national mover rate increased from 8.4% in 2020 (the lowest rate since the Pew Research Center began tracking the data) to 9.3% in 2021. According to the new data, 30 million people changed residences in the U.S. within the past year. 81.7% of all movers stayed within the same state. Renters were more than five times more likely to move than homeowners. The estimates also reveal that many of the nation’s fastest-growing cities are suburbs. Specifically, big cities within metropolitan areas experienced a net loss of 2.1 million movers, while the suburbs had a net gain of 2.4 million movers. Our projections suggest that in about two decades, movers will be almost twice as likely to be moving to a suburb instead of a city.” and then were asked: “The U.S. government should allow refugees who are fleeing war, persecution, or natural disasters in other countries to come live in the U.S..” Only return an integer from 1 to 7, nothing else.
